title: Talented teen kickboxer left fighting for life after collapsing during national title competition
text:
News Talented teen kickboxer left fighting for life after collapsing during national title fight Scott Marsden, 14, was in a critical condition in hospital after needing urgent medical attention during an English title fight in Leeds on Saturday Share Scott Marsden collapsed during a kickboxing competition (Photo: Crowdfunder) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A schoolboy was left fighting for life in hospital last night after collapsing during a national kickboxing competition . 
Scott Marsden, 14, needed urgent medical attention during an English title fight in Leeds on Saturday. 
West Yorkshire Police said the incident was not being treated as suspicious. 
A force spokesman said: "At 1.20pm on Sunday, police were contacted by medical staff at Leeds General Infirmary reporting a 14-year-old boy who was in a critical condition after collapsing during an organised kickboxing contest at Alexandra Mill, Morley, on Saturday night. Read More The 14-year-old was in a critical condition in hospital (Photo: Crowdfunder) 
"The family of the boy are at the hospital and have been spoken to by officers. 
"Inquiries are being carried out into the circumstances." 
Scott is believed to be a member of Marsden's All Styles Kickboxing, in Sheffield. 
The club posted a statement on Facebook on Sunday, which said training was cancelled until further notice. 
A post written earlier in the day said: "Unfortunately, (Saturday) night's English title fight had to be stopped due to Scotty needing immediate medical attention." 
The post said the fight was very close when it was halted. Read More Penzance bus stop crash horror as teenage boy left seriously injured as car mounts pavement Talened Scott is a Sheffield-based kickboxer 
"There was no way to foresee the fight ending in such a way as at no point were either ever in any overwhelming danger from each other," it added. 
"Everyone is still in shock as there were simply no signs to suggest the fight needed to be stopped. 
"The referee stepped in to protect Scott as soon as he could, which meant Scott did not hit the canvas and was laid down and straight into recovery position. 
"Scott was then taken to hospital to undergo tests and scans, where he is stable but not out of the woods." Like us on Facebook
